comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/27331537@N06] Trams had ceased running in George Street Sydney by the time this shot was taken. The overhead wires had been removed, but the tracks remained.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Is that a zebra crossing (on busy George Street!) I spy at the bottom of the frame? What were they thinking? Perhaps traffic was more sedentary in the late 50s/early 60s ...

comment.author: 71200216@N08
comment._content: and the trams will be back by the end of this decade. Back to the future.....

comment._content: awesome shot. when cars used to use george street

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: There are at least 3 FB Holdens in the photo,   which they only started making in Melbourne on 14 January 1960,   so the 1 Jan 1960 looks just slightly ambitious.   Maybe March 1960

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: I am still bamboozled by that car in the left foreground.

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Ben, not a Zebra Crossing, something to do with the former tramway 'Safety Zone' that used to be on the Goulburn Street corner (I think!). Note that it doesn't continue to the eastern side of the road.

comment._content: does anyone know when the tracks on George street were removed?

comment._content: Excellent amazing shot

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Ben, I stand corrected! I'd forgotten that we had zebra crossings as early as that. Talk about bending the evidence! Good work! [http://www.flickr.com/photos/27331537@N06] Certainly a mid-week shot. And the traffic got worse! Compelling case for a 'western distributor'.

comment.author: 21624712@N07
comment._content: The Woolworths building was previously the Bebarfalds building. Bebarfalds sold furniture and I think must have had some other departments as well. I have a photograph of me with Santa with the Bebarfalds name proclaimed in the pic. I think I was about 3 years old at the time.

comment.author: 21647809@N04

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: The car on the lower right corner is an FE Holden made between 1956 and 1958

comment.author: 13411027@N00
comment._content: Thank you for posting this photo in Flickr's Car Memories and Guesses Group www.flickr.com/groups/car_memories_guesses/ I think I can ID three more cars today, First the car at lower right has a straight horizontal crease that begins at the start of the rear wheel well and goes back all the way to the rear. That's typical of the 'big' Toyota Crown about 1960 (pre-Corona) that began to be sold in the US in 1959 as a 'Toyopet Crown.' There's a second one in the same area, farther back, just look for the crease at the rear wheel. I think I see a Fiat 1100 in the center of the photo just to our left of the Austin Noted above. Regarding the big car at the lower left, I'm thinking it is a 1961 Pontiac (USA). These would have been available in the US and Canada around 1 October, 1960. Remember that US cars changed noticeably every single year back then. Here's an advert from the same angle: . www.google.com/imgres?sa=X&biw=1032&bih=455&t... .

comment.author: 32109282@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/13411027@N00] Grant, you are quite right about the 1961 Pontiac (a Parisienne pillarless hardtop, 283 Powerglide), but production of them by Holden probably didn't start until mid-1961, so this has to be later than that.  Also, I see a Falcon wagon right in the middle of the scrum and production of the wagons started in November 1960.  Because of the high taxes on imported cars, every car in this picture was at least assembled in Australia.

comment.author: 71084193@N00
comment._content: Remarkable to note THREE volkswagen "beetles".....+ possibly a fourth away at the back.....were these assembled in Australia...?

comment.author: 32109282@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nevis_beeman] Yes, Volkswagens were built in Melbourne.
